# What Makes a Good Metric?  
ä»€ä¹ˆæ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªå¥½çš„æŒ‡æ ‡ï¼Ÿ

Here are some rules of thumb for what makes a good metricâ€”a number that will drive the changes youâ€™re looking for.  
ä»¥ä¸‹æ˜¯ä¸€äº›å…³äºä»€ä¹ˆæ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªå¥½æŒ‡æ ‡çš„ç»éªŒæ³•åˆ™â€”â€”ä¸€ä¸ªèƒ½æ¨åŠ¨ä½ æ‰€æœŸæœ›å˜åŒ–çš„æ•°å­—ã€‚

A good metric is comparative. Being able to compare a metric to other time periods, groups of users, or competitors helps you understand which way things are moving. â€œIncreased conversion from last weekâ€ is more meaningful than $^{66}2\%$ conversion.â€  
ä¸€ä¸ªå¥½çš„æŒ‡æ ‡æ˜¯å…·æœ‰å¯æ¯”æ€§çš„ã€‚èƒ½å¤Ÿå°†æŒ‡æ ‡ä¸å…¶ä»–æ—¶é—´æ®µã€ç”¨æˆ·ç¾¤ä½“æˆ–ç«äº‰å¯¹æ‰‹è¿›è¡Œæ¯”è¾ƒï¼Œæœ‰åŠ©äºä½ ç†è§£äº‹ç‰©çš„å‘å±•æ–¹å‘ã€‚â€œä¸Šå‘¨è½¬åŒ–ç‡çš„å¢åŠ â€æ¯”â€œ0%çš„è½¬åŒ–ç‡â€æ›´æœ‰æ„ä¹‰ã€‚

A good metric is understandable. If people canâ€™t remember it and discuss it, itâ€™s much harder to turn a change in the data into a change in the culture.  
ä¸€ä¸ªå¥½çš„æŒ‡æ ‡æ˜¯æ˜“äºç†è§£çš„ã€‚å¦‚æœäººä»¬è®°ä¸ä½å®ƒå¹¶è®¨è®ºå®ƒï¼Œå°†æ•°æ®å˜åŒ–è½¬åŒ–ä¸ºæ–‡åŒ–å˜åŒ–å°±ä¼šæ›´åŠ å›°éš¾ã€‚

A good metric is a ratio or a rate. Accountants and financial analysts have several ratios they look at to understand, at a glance, the fundamental health of a company.\* You need some, too.  
ä¸€ä¸ªå¥½çš„æŒ‡æ ‡åº”è¯¥æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªæ¯”ç‡æˆ–é€Ÿç‡ã€‚ä¼šè®¡å¸ˆå’Œè´¢åŠ¡åˆ†æå¸ˆä¼šæŸ¥çœ‹å¤šä¸ªæ¯”ç‡æ¥å¿«é€Ÿäº†è§£å…¬å¸çš„åŸºæœ¬å¥åº·çŠ¶å†µã€‚ä½ ä¹Ÿéœ€è¦ä¸€äº›è¿™æ ·çš„æŒ‡æ ‡ã€‚

There are several reasons ratios tend to be the best metrics:  
æ¯”ç‡é€šå¸¸æ˜¯æœ€å¥½çš„æŒ‡æ ‡æœ‰ä»¥ä¸‹å‡ ä¸ªåŸå› ï¼š

â€¢ Ratios are easier to act on. Think about driving a car. Distance travelled is informational. But speedâ€”distance per hourâ€”is something you can act on, because it tells you about your current state, and whether you need to go faster or slower to get to your destination on time. â€¢ Ratios are inherently comparative. If you compare a daily metric to the same metric over a month, youâ€™ll see whether youâ€™re looking at a sudden spike or a long-term trend. In a car, speed is one metric, but speed right now over average speed this hour shows you a lot about whether youâ€™re accelerating or slowing down. â€¢ Ratios are also good for comparing factors that are somehow opposed, or for which thereâ€™s an inherent tension. This ratio might suggest whether or not you should be breaking the speed limit.

Leaving our car analogy for a moment, consider a startup with free and paid versions of its software. One other thing youâ€™ll notice about metrics is that they often come in pairs. Conversion rate (the percentage of people who buy something) is tied to time-to-purchase (how long it takes someone to buy something). Together, they tell you a lot about your cash flow. Similarly, viral coefficient (the number of people a user successfully invites to your service) and viral cycle time (how long it takes them to invite others) drive your adoption rate. As you start to explore the numbers that underpin your business, youâ€™ll notice these pairs. Behind them lurks a fundamental metric like revenue, cash flow, or user adoption.

# Qualitative versus quantitative metrics  
å®šæ€§æŒ‡æ ‡ä¸å®šé‡æŒ‡æ ‡

Qualitative metrics are unstructured, anecdotal, revealing, and hard to aggregate; quantitative metrics involve numbers and statistics, and provide hard numbers but less insight.

# Vanity versus actionable metrics

Exploratory metrics are speculative and try to find unknown insights to give you the upper hand, while reporting metrics keep you abreast of normal, managerial, day-to-day operations.

# Leading versus lagging metrics

Leading metrics give you a predictive understanding of the future; lagging metrics explain the past. Leading metrics are better because you still have time to act on themâ€”the horse hasnâ€™t left the barn yet.

# Correlated versus causal metrics  
ç›¸å…³æŒ‡æ ‡ä¸å› æœæŒ‡æ ‡

If two metrics change together, theyâ€™re correlated, but if one metric causes another metric to change, theyâ€™re causal. If you find a causal relationship between something you want (like revenue) and something you can control (like which ad you show), then you can change the future.

Quantitative data is easy to understand. Itâ€™s the numbers we track and measureâ€”for example, sports scores and movie ratings. åˆ†æå­¦åˆ°çš„æ•™è®­

The key to Mikeâ€™s success with Circle of Moms was his ability to dig into the data and look for meaningful patterns and opportunities. Thereâ€™s a â€œcritical massâ€ of engagement necessary for any community to take off. Mild success may not give you escape velocity. As a result, itâ€™s better to have fervent engagement with a smaller, more easily addressable target market. Virality requires focus.

# Leading Versus Lagging Metrics  
é¢†å…ˆæŒ‡æ ‡ä¸æ»åæŒ‡æ ‡

Both leading and lagging metrics are useful, but they serve different purposes.  
é¢†å…ˆæŒ‡æ ‡å’Œæ»åæŒ‡æ ‡éƒ½æ˜¯æœ‰ç”¨çš„ï¼Œä½†å®ƒä»¬æœåŠ¡äºä¸åŒçš„ç›®çš„ã€‚

A leading metric (sometimes called a leading indicator) tries to predict the future. For example, the current number of prospects in your sales funnel gives you a sense of how many new customers youâ€™ll acquire in the future.  
ä¸»è¦æŒ‡æ ‡ï¼ˆæœ‰æ—¶ä¹Ÿç§°ä¸ºé¢†å…ˆæŒ‡æ ‡ï¼‰è¯•å›¾é¢„æµ‹æœªæ¥ã€‚ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼Œé”€å”®æ¼æ–—ä¸­å½“å‰çš„æ½œåœ¨å®¢æˆ·æ•°é‡å¯ä»¥è®©ä½ äº†è§£æœªæ¥å°†è·å¾—å¤šå°‘æ–°å®¢æˆ·ã€‚

If the current number of prospects is very small, youâ€™re not likely to add many new customers. You can increase the number of prospects and expect an increase in new customers.  
å¦‚æœå½“å‰çš„æ½œåœ¨å®¢æˆ·æ•°é‡å¾ˆå°‘ï¼Œä½ å¯èƒ½ä¸ä¼šå¢åŠ å¾ˆå¤šæ–°å®¢æˆ·ã€‚ä½ å¯ä»¥å¢åŠ æ½œåœ¨å®¢æˆ·çš„æ•°é‡ï¼Œå¹¶æœŸå¾…æ–°å®¢æˆ·çš„å¢åŠ ã€‚

On the other hand, a lagging metric, such as churn (which is the number of customers who leave in a given time period) gives you an indication that thereâ€™s a problemâ€”but by the time youâ€™re able to collect the data and identify the problem, itâ€™s too late. The customers who churned out arenâ€™t coming back. That doesnâ€™t mean you canâ€™t act on a lagging metric (i.e., work to improve churn and then measure it again), but itâ€™s akin to closing the barn door after the horses have left. New horses wonâ€™t leave, but youâ€™ve already lost a few.  
å¦ä¸€æ–¹é¢ï¼Œæ»åæŒ‡æ ‡ï¼ˆå¦‚æµå¤±ç‡ï¼Œå³ä¸€å®šæ—¶æœŸå†…ç¦»å¼€çš„å®¢æˆ·æ•°é‡ï¼‰ä¼šç»™ä½ ä¸€ä¸ªé—®é¢˜çš„è¿¹è±¡â€”â€”ä½†ç­‰åˆ°ä½ æ”¶é›†æ•°æ®å¹¶è¯†åˆ«å‡ºé—®é¢˜æ—¶ï¼Œå·²ç»å¤ªæ™šäº†ã€‚æµå¤±çš„å®¢æˆ·ä¸ä¼šå›æ¥äº†ã€‚è¿™ä¸æ„å‘³ç€ä½ ä¸èƒ½æ ¹æ®æ»åæŒ‡æ ‡é‡‡å–è¡ŒåŠ¨ï¼ˆå³ï¼ŒåŠªåŠ›æ”¹å–„æµå¤±ç‡ï¼Œç„¶åå†æ¬¡æµ‹é‡å®ƒï¼‰ï¼Œä½†è¿™å°±åƒåœ¨é©¬ç¦»å¼€é©¬å©åæ‰å…³ä¸Šé©¬å©çš„é—¨ã€‚æ–°çš„é©¬ä¸ä¼šç¦»å¼€ï¼Œä½†ä½ å·²ç»å¤±å»äº†ä¸€äº›ã€‚

In the early days of your startup, you wonâ€™t have enough data to know how a current metric relates to one down the road, so measure lagging metrics at first. Lagging metrics are still useful and can provide a solid baseline of performance. For leading indicators to work, you need to be able to do cohort analysis and compare groups of customers over periods of time.

In Canada, the use of winter tires is correlated with a decrease in accidents. # Analytics Lessons Learned  
åˆ†æå­¦ç»éªŒæ•™è®­

First, know your customer. Thereâ€™s no substitute for engaging with customers and users directly. All the numbers in the world canâ€™t explain why something is happening. Pick up the phone right now and call a customer, even one whoâ€™s disengaged.

Second, make early assumptions and set targets for what you think success looks like, but donâ€™t experiment yourself into oblivion. Lower the bar if necessary, but not for the sake of getting over it: thatâ€™s just cheating. Use qualitative data to understand what value youâ€™re creating and adjust only if the new line in the sand reflects how customers (in specific segments) are using your product.

# Segments, Cohorts, A/B Testing, and Multivariate Analysis  
ç”¨æˆ·ç»†åˆ†ã€é˜Ÿåˆ—åˆ†æã€A/B æµ‹è¯•å’Œå¤šå˜é‡åˆ†æ

Testing is at the heart of Lean Analytics. Testing usually involves comparing two things against each other through segmentation, cohort analysis, or A/B testing. These are important concepts for anyone trying to perform the kind of scientific comparison needed to justify a change, so weâ€™ll explain them in some detail here.

# Segmentation  
ç”¨æˆ·ç»†åˆ†

A segment is simply a group that shares some common characteristic. It might be users who run Firefox, or restaurant patrons who make reservations rather than walking in, or passengers who buy first-class tickets, or parents who drive minivans.  
ç”¨æˆ·ç»†åˆ†å°±æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªå…±äº«æŸäº›å…±åŒç‰¹å¾çš„å°ç»„ã€‚å®ƒå¯èƒ½æ˜¯ä½¿ç”¨ Firefox çš„ç”¨æˆ·ï¼Œæˆ–è€…é¢„è®¢é¤å…è€Œä¸æ˜¯èµ°è¿›æ¥çš„é¤å…é¡¾å®¢ï¼Œæˆ–è€…æ˜¯è´­ä¹°å¤´ç­‰èˆ±ç¥¨çš„ä¹˜å®¢ï¼Œæˆ–è€…æ˜¯é©¾é©¶æ—…è¡Œè½¦çš„çˆ¶æ¯ã€‚

On websites, you segment visitors according to a range of technical and demographic information, then compare one segment to another. If visitors using the Firefox browser have significantly fewer purchases, do additional testing to find out why. If a disproportionate number of engaged users are coming from Australia, survey them to discover why, and then try to replicate that success in other markets.  
åœ¨ç½‘ç«™ä¸Šï¼Œæ‚¨æ ¹æ®ä¸€ç³»åˆ—æŠ€æœ¯å’Œäººå£ç»Ÿè®¡ä¿¡æ¯å¯¹è®¿å®¢è¿›è¡Œç»†åˆ†ï¼Œç„¶åæ¯”è¾ƒä¸åŒçš„ç»†åˆ†ç¾¤ä½“ã€‚å¦‚æœä½¿ç”¨ Firefox æµè§ˆå™¨çš„è®¿å®¢è´­ä¹°é‡æ˜¾è‘—è¾ƒä½ï¼Œè¯·è¿›è¡Œé¢å¤–æµ‹è¯•ä»¥æ‰¾å‡ºåŸå› ã€‚å¦‚æœæ¥è‡ªæ¾³å¤§åˆ©äºšçš„å‚ä¸ç”¨æˆ·æ¯”ä¾‹è¿‡é«˜ï¼Œè¯·å¯¹ä»–ä»¬è¿›è¡Œè°ƒæŸ¥ä»¥å‘ç°åŸå› ï¼Œç„¶åå°è¯•åœ¨å…¶ä»–å¸‚åœºå¤åˆ¶è¿™ç§æˆåŠŸã€‚

Segmentation works for any industry and any form of marketing, not just for websites. Direct mail marketers have been segmenting for decades with great success.

# Cohort Analysis  
ç¾¤ç»„åˆ†æ

A second kind of analysis, which compares similar groups over time, is cohort analysis. As you build and test your product, youâ€™ll iterate constantly. Users who join you in the first week will have a different experience from those who join later on. For example, all of your users might go through an initial free trial, usage, payment, and abandonment cycle. As this happens, youâ€™ll make changes to your business model. The users who experienced the trial in month one will have a different onboarding experience from those who experience it in month five. How did that affect their churn? To find out, we use cohort analysis.

Each group of users is a cohortâ€”participants in an experiment across their lifecycle. You can compare cohorts against one another to see if, on the whole, key metrics are getting better over time. Hereâ€™s an example of why cohort analysis is critical for startups.

A cohort analysis presents a much clearer perspective. In this example, poor monetization in early months was diluting the overall health of the metrics. The January cohortâ€”the first rowâ€”spent \\5$in its first month, then tapered off to only$$0.50$in its fifth month. But first-month spending is growing dramatically, and the drop-off seems better, too: Aprilâ€™s cohort spent$$8$in its first month and$$7$ in its second month. A company that seemed stalled is in fact flourishing. And you know what metric to focus on: drop-off in sales after the first month.

This kind of reporting allows you to see patterns clearly against the lifecycle of a customer, rather than slicing across all customers blindly without accounting for the natural cycle a customer undergoes. Cohort analysis can be done for revenue, churn, viral word of mouth, support costs, or any other metric you care about.

# A/B and Multivariate Testing  
A/B æµ‹è¯•å’Œå¤šå˜é‡æµ‹è¯•

Cohort experiments that compare groups like the one in Table 2-2 are called longitudinal studies, since the data is collected along the natural lifespan of a customer group. By contrast, studies in which different groups of test subjects are given different experiences at the same time are called cross-sectional studies. Showing half of the visitors a blue link and half of them a green link in order to see which group is more likely to click that link is a cross-sectional study. When weâ€™re comparing one attribute of a subjectâ€™s experience, such as link color, and assuming everything else is equal, weâ€™re doing A/B testing.

æ•°æ®é©±åŠ¨ä¸æ•°æ®æŒ‡å¯¼

Data is a powerful thing. It can be addictive, making you overanalyze everything. But much of what we actually do is unconscious, based on past experience and pragmatism. And with good reason: relying on wisdom and experience, rather than rigid analysis, helps us get through our day. After all, you donâ€™t run A/B testing before deciding what pants to put on in the morning; if you did, youâ€™d never get out the door.  
æ•°æ®æ˜¯ä¸€ä»¶å¼ºå¤§çš„äº‹æƒ…ã€‚å®ƒå¯ä»¥è®©äººä¸Šç˜¾ï¼Œè®©ä½ è¿‡åº¦åˆ†æä¸€åˆ‡ã€‚ä½†æˆ‘ä»¬æ‰€åšçš„å¾ˆå¤šå…¶å®æ˜¯æ— æ„è¯†çš„ï¼ŒåŸºäºè¿‡å»çš„ç»éªŒå’Œå®ç”¨ä¸»ä¹‰ã€‚è¿™ä¹Ÿæœ‰å……åˆ†ç†ç”±ï¼šä¾é æ™ºæ…§å’Œç»éªŒï¼Œè€Œä¸æ˜¯åƒµåŒ–çš„åˆ†æï¼Œèƒ½å¸®åŠ©æˆ‘ä»¬åº¦è¿‡ä¸€å¤©ã€‚æ¯•ç«Ÿï¼Œä½ ä¸ä¼šåœ¨æ—©ä¸Šå†³å®šç©¿ä»€ä¹ˆè£¤å­ä¹‹å‰è¿›è¡Œ A/B æµ‹è¯•ï¼›å¦‚æœä½ é‚£æ ·åšï¼Œä½ æ°¸è¿œä¹Ÿå‡ºä¸å»ã€‚

One of the criticisms of Lean Startup is that itâ€™s too data-driven. Rather than be a slave to the data, these critics say, we should use it as a tool. We should be data-informed, not data-driven. Mostly, theyâ€™re just being lazy, and looking for reasons not to do the hard work. But sometimes, they have a point: using data to optimize one part of your business, without stepping back and looking at the big picture, can be dangerousâ€”even fatal.

In mathematics, a local maximum is the largest value of a function within a given neighborhood.\* That doesnâ€™t mean itâ€™s the largest possible value, just the largest one in a particular range. As an analogy, consider a lake on a mountainside. The water isnâ€™t at its lowest possible levelâ€”that would be sea levelâ€”but itâ€™s at the lowest possible level in the area surrounding the lake.

Optimization is all about finding the lowest or highest values of a particular function. To understand the problem with constrained optimization, imagine that youâ€™re given three wheels and asked to evolve the best, most stable vehicle. In his book River Out Of Eden (Basic Books), Richard Dawkins uses the analogy of a flowing river to describe evolution. Evolution, he explains, can create the eye. In fact, it can create dozens of versions of it, for wasps, octopods, humans, eagles, and whales. What it canâ€™t do well is go backward: once you have an eye thatâ€™s useful, slight mutations donâ€™t usually yield improvements. A human wonâ€™t evolve an eagleâ€™s eye, because the intermediate steps all result in bad eyesight.

# Lean Startup and Big Vision  
ç²¾ç›Šåˆ›ä¸šå’Œå®å¤§æ„¿æ™¯

Some entrepreneurs are maniacally, almost compulsively, data-obsessed, but tend to get mired in analysis paralysis. Others are casual, shootfrom-the-hip intuitionists who ignore data unless it suits them, and pivot lazily from idea to idea without discipline. At the root of this divide is the fundamental challenge that Lean Startup advocates face: how do you have a minimum viable product and a hugely compelling vision at the same time?

Plenty of founders use Lean Startup as an excuse to start a company without a vision. â€œItâ€™s so easy to start a company these days.â€ They reason, â€œthe barriers are so low that everyone can do it, right?â€ Yet having a big vision is important: starting a company without one makes you susceptible to outside influences, be they from customers, investors, competition, press, or anything else. Without a big vision, youâ€™ll lack purpose, and over time youâ€™ll find yourself wandering aimlessly.  
è®¸å¤šåˆ›å§‹äººåˆ©ç”¨ç²¾ç›Šåˆ›ä¸šä½œä¸ºæ²¡æœ‰æ„¿æ™¯å°±åˆ›åŠå…¬å¸çš„å€Ÿå£ã€‚â€œå¦‚ä»Šåˆ›åŠå…¬å¸å¤ªå®¹æ˜“äº†ã€‚â€ä»–ä»¬è¿™æ ·æ¨ç†ï¼Œâ€œé—¨æ§›è¿™ä¹ˆä½ï¼Œæ¯ä¸ªäººéƒ½èƒ½åšï¼Œå¯¹å§ï¼Ÿâ€ç„¶è€Œæ‹¥æœ‰ä¸€ä¸ªå®å¤§çš„æ„¿æ™¯éå¸¸é‡è¦ï¼šæ²¡æœ‰æ„¿æ™¯åœ°åˆ›åŠå…¬å¸ä¼šè®©ä½ å®¹æ˜“å—åˆ°å¤–ç•Œçš„å½±å“ï¼Œæ— è®ºæ˜¯æ¥è‡ªå®¢æˆ·ã€æŠ•èµ„è€…ã€ç«äº‰è€…ã€åª’ä½“ï¼Œè¿˜æ˜¯å…¶ä»–ä»»ä½•æ–¹é¢ã€‚æ²¡æœ‰å®å¤§çš„æ„¿æ™¯ï¼Œä½ ä¼šç¼ºä¹ç›®æ ‡ï¼Œéšç€æ—¶é—´çš„æ¨ç§»ï¼Œä½ ä¼šå‘ç°è‡ªå·±åœ¨æ¼«æ— ç›®çš„åœ°æ¸¸è¡ã€‚

So if a big, hairy, audacious vision is importantâ€”one with a changing-theworld type goalâ€”how does that reconcile with the step-by-step, alwaysquestioning approach of Lean Startup?  
é‚£ä¹ˆå¦‚æœéœ€è¦ä¸€ä¸ªå®å¤§ã€è‰°å·¨ã€é›„å¿ƒå‹ƒå‹ƒçš„æ„¿æ™¯â€”â€”ä¸€ä¸ªå…·æœ‰æ”¹å˜ä¸–ç•Œç±»å‹çš„ç›®æ ‡â€”â€”è¿™ä¸ç²¾ç›Šåˆ›ä¸šçš„é€æ­¥ã€ä¸æ–­è´¨ç–‘çš„æ–¹æ³•å¦‚ä½•åè°ƒä¸€è‡´ï¼Ÿ

The answer is actually pretty simple. You need to think of Lean Startup as the process you use to move toward and achieve your vision.  
ç­”æ¡ˆå®é™…ä¸Šç›¸å½“ç®€å•ã€‚ä½ éœ€è¦å°†ç²¾ç›Šåˆ›ä¸šè§†ä¸ºä¸€ä¸ªå¸®åŠ©ä½ å®ç°æ„¿æ™¯çš„è¿‡ç¨‹ã€‚

We sometimes remind early-stage founders that, in many ways, they arenâ€™t building a product. Theyâ€™re building a tool to learn what product to build. This helps separate the task at handâ€”finding a sustainable business modelâ€”from the screens, lines of code, and mailing lists theyâ€™ve carefully built along the way.  
æˆ‘ä»¬æœ‰æ—¶ä¼šæé†’æ—©æœŸé˜¶æ®µçš„åˆ›å§‹äººï¼Œåœ¨å¾ˆå¤šæ–¹é¢ï¼Œä»–ä»¬å¹¶ä¸æ˜¯åœ¨æ„å»ºä¸€ä¸ªäº§å“ã€‚ä»–ä»¬æ˜¯åœ¨æ„å»ºä¸€ä¸ªå­¦ä¹ è¦æ„å»ºä»€ä¹ˆäº§å“çš„å·¥å…·ã€‚è¿™æœ‰åŠ©äºå°†å½“å‰çš„ä»»åŠ¡â€”â€”æ‰¾åˆ°å¯æŒç»­çš„å•†ä¸šæ¨¡å¼â€”â€”ä¸ä»–ä»¬æ²¿é€”ç²¾å¿ƒæ„å»ºçš„å±å¹•ã€ä»£ç è¡Œå’Œé‚®ä»¶åˆ—è¡¨åŒºåˆ†å¼€æ¥ã€‚

Lean Startup is focused on learning above everything else, and encourages broad thinking, exploration, and experimentation. Itâ€™s not about mindlessly going through the motions of build $\rightarrow$ measure $\rightarrow$ learnâ€”itâ€™s about really understanding whatâ€™s going on and being open to new possibilities.  
ç²¾ç›Šåˆ›ä¸šä¸“æ³¨äºå­¦ä¹ ï¼Œé¼“åŠ±å¹¿æ³›æ€è€ƒã€æ¢ç´¢å’Œå®éªŒã€‚å®ƒä¸æ˜¯ç›²ç›®åœ°èµ°è¿‡æ„å»º $\rightarrow$ è¡¡é‡ $\rightarrow$ å­¦ä¹ çš„è¿‡ç¨‹â€”â€”è€Œæ˜¯çœŸæ­£ç†è§£æ­£åœ¨å‘ç”Ÿçš„äº‹æƒ…ï¼Œå¹¶å¯¹æ–°çš„å¯èƒ½æ€§æŒå¼€æ”¾æ€åº¦ã€‚

Be Lean. Donâ€™t be small. Weâ€™ve talked to founders who want to be the leading provider in their state or province. Why not the world? Even the Allies had to pick a beachhead, but landing in Normandy didnâ€™t mean they lacked a big vision. They just found a good place to start.

Some people believe Lean Startup encourages that smallness, but in fact, used properly, Lean Startup helps expand your vision, because youâ€™re encouraged to question everything. As you dig deeper and peel away more layers of what youâ€™re doingâ€”whether youâ€™re looking at problems, solutions, customers, revenue, or anything elseâ€”youâ€™re likely to find a lot more than you expected. If youâ€™re opportunistic about it, you can expand your vision and understand how to get there faster, all at the same time.

ç—…æ¯’å¼ä¼ æ’­å¼•æ“

Virality is all about getting the word out. Virality is attractive because it compoundsâ€”if every user adds another 1.5 users, your user base will grow infinitely until youâ€™ve saturated all users.\*  
ç—…æ¯’å¼ä¼ æ’­çš„å…¨éƒ¨æ„ä¹‰åœ¨äºè®©æ›´å¤šäººçŸ¥é“ã€‚ç—…æ¯’å¼ä¼ æ’­ä¹‹æ‰€ä»¥å¸å¼•äººï¼Œæ˜¯å› ä¸ºå®ƒä¼šæŒ‡æ•°çº§å¢é•¿â€”â€”å¦‚æœæ¯ä¸ªç”¨æˆ·èƒ½å¸¦æ¥ 1.5 ä¸ªæ–°ç”¨æˆ·ï¼Œä½ çš„ç”¨æˆ·ç¾¤å°†æ— é™å¢é•¿ï¼Œç›´åˆ°æ‰€æœ‰ç”¨æˆ·éƒ½è¢«è¦†ç›–ä¸ºæ­¢ã€‚

The key metric for this engine is the viral coefficientâ€”the number of new users that each user brings on. Because this is compounding (the users they bring, in turn, bring their own users), the metric measures how many users are brought in with each viral cycle. Growth comes from a viral coefficient of greater than one, but you also have to factor in churn and loss. The bigger the coefficient, the faster you grow.

The third engine of growth is payment. Itâ€™s usually premature to turn this engine on before you know that your product is sticky and viral. Getting paid is, in some ways, the ultimate metric for identifying a sustainable business model. å¦‚ä½•ä½¿ç”¨ç²¾ç›Šç”»å¸ƒ

Unlike a traditional business plan, you should use and update the Lean Canvas continuously. Itâ€™s a â€œliving, breathingâ€ plan, not a hypothetical tome of nonsense that you throw out the minute you start actually working on your startup. Once youâ€™ve filled out the Lean Canvas (or most of it), you start running experiments to validate or invalidate what youâ€™ve hypothesized.

In its simplest form, think of each box as a â€œpass/failâ€: if your experiments fail, you donâ€™t go to the next box; rather, you keep experimenting until you hit a wall completely or get to the next step. The only exception is the â€œKey metricsâ€ box, which is meant to keep a record of the most important metrics youâ€™re tracking. You donâ€™t run experiments on this box, but itâ€™s important to fill it out anyway because itâ€™s definitely open to debate and discussion.

Each of the boxes in Ashâ€™s canvas has relevant metrics you need to track, as outlined in Table 5-2 (the canvas actually has a box for metrics, which should get updated each time you focus on something different in the canvas). These metrics either tie your one-page business model to reality by confirming each box, or they send you back to the drawing board. # The Long Funnel  
é•¿æ¼æ–—

In the early days of the Web, transactional websites had relatively simple conversion funnels. Visitors came to the home page, navigated to the product they wanted, entered payment information, and confirmed their order.  
åœ¨äº’è”ç½‘çš„æ—©æœŸï¼Œäº¤æ˜“æ€§ç½‘ç«™æœ‰ç›¸å¯¹ç®€å•çš„è½¬åŒ–æ¼æ–—ã€‚è®¿å®¢æ¥åˆ°ä¸»é¡µï¼Œå¯¼èˆªåˆ°ä»–ä»¬æƒ³è¦çš„äº§å“ï¼Œè¾“å…¥æ”¯ä»˜ä¿¡æ¯ï¼Œå¹¶ç¡®è®¤è®¢å•ã€‚

No more. Todayâ€™s funnel extends well beyond the front door of a website, across myriad social networks, sharing platforms, affiliates, and pricecomparison sites. Both offline and online factors influence a single purchase. Customers may make several tentative visits prior to a conversion.  
ä¸å†å¦‚æ­¤ã€‚å¦‚ä»Šçš„æ¼æ–—è¿œä¸æ­¢ç½‘ç«™çš„å…¥å£ï¼Œå®ƒè·¨è¶Šäº†æ— æ•°ç¤¾äº¤ç½‘ç»œã€åˆ†äº«å¹³å°ã€è”ç›Ÿè¥é”€å’Œæ¯”ä»·ç½‘ç«™ã€‚çº¿ä¸Šå’Œçº¿ä¸‹çš„å› ç´ éƒ½ä¼šå½±å“å•æ¬¡è´­ä¹°ã€‚é¡¾å®¢å¯èƒ½åœ¨è½¬åŒ–ä¹‹å‰è¿›è¡Œå¤šæ¬¡è¯•æ¢æ€§è®¿é—®ã€‚

We call this the Long Funnel. Itâ€™s a way of understanding how you first come to someoneâ€™s attention, and the journey she takes from that initial awareness through to a goal you want her to complete (such as making a purchase, creating content, or sharing a message). Often, measuring a long funnel involves injecting some kind of tracking into the initial signal, so you can follow the user as she winds up on your site, which many analytics packages can now report. Figure 5-3 shows the Social Visitors Flow report in Google Analytics, for example.

# The Lean Analytics Stages and Gates  
Lean Analytics é˜¶æ®µå’Œå…³å¡

Having reviewed these frameworks, we needed a model that identified the distinct stages a startup usually goes through, and what the â€œgatingâ€ metrics should be that indicate itâ€™s time to move to the next stage. The five stages we identified are Empathy, Stickiness, Virality, Revenue, and Scale. We believe most startups go through these stages, and in order to move from one to the next they need to achieve certain goals with respect to the metrics theyâ€™re tracking.

# The Discipline of One Metric That Matters  
â€œæœ€é‡è¦çš„æŒ‡æ ‡â€çš„çºªå¾‹

Founders are magpies, chasing the shiniest new thing they see. They often use the pivot as an enabler for chronic ADD, rather than as a way to iterate through ideas in a methodical fashion.  
åˆ›å§‹äººæ˜¯å–œé¹Šï¼Œè¿½é€ä»–ä»¬çœ‹åˆ°çš„æœ€æ–°æœ€é—ªäº®çš„ä¸œè¥¿ã€‚ä»–ä»¬ç»å¸¸ä½¿ç”¨è½¬å‹ä½œä¸ºä¸€ç§æ…¢æ€§æ³¨æ„åŠ›ç¼ºé™·éšœç¢çš„ä¿ƒè¿›æ‰‹æ®µï¼Œè€Œä¸æ˜¯ä½œä¸ºä¸€ç§ä»¥ç³»ç»Ÿçš„æ–¹å¼è¿­ä»£æƒ³æ³•çš„æ–¹æ³•ã€‚

But one of the keys to startup success is achieving real focus and having the discipline to maintain it. You may succeed if youâ€™re unfocused, but itâ€™ll be by accident. Youâ€™ll spend a lot more time wandering aimlessly, and the lessons learned are more painful and harder-won. If thereâ€™s any secret to success for a startup, itâ€™s focus.  
ä½†åˆ›ä¸šæˆåŠŸçš„å…³é”®ä¹‹ä¸€æ˜¯çœŸæ­£åœ°é›†ä¸­æ³¨æ„åŠ›å’Œæ‹¥æœ‰ç»´æŒè¿™ç§ä¸“æ³¨çš„çºªå¾‹ã€‚å¦‚æœä½ ä¸ä¸“æ³¨ï¼Œä¹Ÿè®¸ä¹Ÿèƒ½æˆåŠŸï¼Œä½†é‚£åªæ˜¯å¶ç„¶ã€‚ä½ ä¼šèŠ±æ›´å¤šæ—¶é—´æ¼«æ— ç›®çš„åœ°æ¸¸è¡ï¼Œè€Œå­¦åˆ°çš„æ•™è®­æ›´åŠ ç—›è‹¦å’Œæ¥ä¹‹ä¸æ˜“ã€‚å¦‚æœåˆ›ä¸šæœ‰ä»»ä½•æˆåŠŸçš„ç§˜è¯€ï¼Œé‚£å°±æ˜¯ä¸“æ³¨ã€‚

Focus doesnâ€™t mean myopia. Weâ€™re not saying that thereâ€™s only one metric you care about from the day you wake up with an idea to the day you sell your company. We are, however, saying that at any given time, thereâ€™s one metric you should care about above all else. Boiled down to its very essence, Lean Startup is really about getting you to focus on the right thing, at the right time, with the right mindset.

As noted in Chapter 5, Eric Ries talks about three engines that drive company growth: the sticky engine, the viral engine, and the paid engine. But he cautions that while all successful companies will ultimately use all three engines, itâ€™s better to focus on one engine at a time. For example, you might make your product sticky for its core users, then use that to grow virally, and then use the user base to grow revenue. Thatâ€™s focus.

In the world of analytics and data, this means picking a single metric thatâ€™s incredibly important for the step youâ€™re currently working through in your startup. We call this the One Metric That Matters (OMTM).

The OMTM is the one number youâ€™re completely focused on above everything else for your current stage. Looking at CLV (customer lifetime value) isnâ€™t meaningful when youâ€™re validating a problem, but it might be the right metric to focus on as youâ€™re approaching product/market fit.

Youâ€™ll always track and review multiple numbers. Some will be important: these are your key performance indicators (KPIs), which youâ€™ll track and report every day. Picking the OMTM lets you run more controlled experiments quickly and compare the results more effectively. Remember: the One Metric That Matters changes over time. When youâ€™re focused on acquiring users (and converting them into customers), your OMTM may be tied to which acquisition channels are working best or the conversion rate from signup to active user. When youâ€™re focused on retention, you may be looking at churn, and experimenting with pricing, features, improving customer support, and so on. The OMTM changes depending on your current stage, and in some cases it will change quickly.

The key here is analytics. You need to segment real, valuable users from drive-by, curious, or detrimental ones. Then you need to make changes that maximize the real users and weed out the bad ones. Each of these use models represents a different tier of engagement, and Fitbit could segment users across these five segments. A product is more than the thing you buy. Itâ€™s the mix of service, branding, fame, street cred, support, packaging, and myriad other factors you pay for. When you purchase an iPhone, youâ€™re also getting a tiny piece of Steve Jobsâ€™s persona.

In the same way, a business model is a combination of things. Itâ€™s what you sell, how you deliver it, how you acquire customers, and how you make money from them.

Many people blur these dimensions of a business model. Weâ€™re guilty of it, too. Freemium isnâ€™t a business modelâ€”itâ€™s a marketing tactic. You can build business models this way, but instead of heads, torsos, and feet, you have several aspects of a business: the acquisition channel, selling tactic, revenue source, product type, and delivery model.  
ä½ å¯ä»¥ç”¨è¿™ç§æ–¹å¼æ„å»ºå•†ä¸šæ¨¡å¼ï¼Œä½†ä»£æ›¿å¤´éƒ¨ã€èº¯å¹²å’Œè„šéƒ¨çš„æ˜¯ï¼Œä½ æœ‰å‡ ä¸ªå•†ä¸šæ–¹é¢ï¼šè·å–æ¸ é“ã€é”€å”®ç­–ç•¥ã€æ”¶å…¥æ¥æºã€äº§å“ç±»å‹å’Œäº¤ä»˜æ¨¡å¼ã€‚

â€¢ The acquisition channel is how people find out about you. â€¢ The selling tactic is how you convince visitors to become users or users to become customers. Generally, you either ask for money or you provide some kind of scarcity or exclusivityâ€”such as a time limit, a capacity limit, the removal of ads, additional functionality, or the desire to keep things to themselvesâ€”to convince them to act. The revenue source is simply how you make money. Money can come from your customers directly (through a payment) or indirectly (through advertising, referrals, analysis of their behavior, content creation, and so on). It can include transactions, subscriptions, consumption-based billing charges, ad revenue, resale of data, donations, and much more. â€¢ The product type is what value your business offers in return for the revenue.

â€¢ Retailers use recommendation engines to anticipate what else a buyer might want, basing their suggestions on past buyers and other users with similar profiles. Few visitors see the same pages as one another.

â€¢ Purchases begin far from the website itself, in social networks, email inboxes, and online communities, making the buying process harder to track.

E-commerce companies make money in a straightforward way: they charge for products, which they then deliver either electronically (e.g., digital downloads on iTunes) or physically (e.g., shipping shoes from Zappos). They spend money to acquire customers through advertising and affiliate referrals. Prices are set based on what the market will bear, or on expectations set by competitors. Some large retailers with the budget and time to invest in it will generate prices algorithmically based on supply, demand, and constant testing, which in some cases leads to absurd pricing or recommendations based on factors such as browser type.

Loyalty-focused e-retailers like Amazon build a recurring relationship with their users. They have a wide variety of products to offer, and buyers return often, so they do everything they can to make purchasing simple and automatic (in Amazonâ€™s case, the company patented the one-click purchase model, which it now licenses to other retailers, including Apple).

Kevin Hillstrom of Mine That Data, a consultancy focused on helping companies understand how their customers interact with advertising, products, brands, and channels, works with a number of e-commerce companies. # Acquisition mode  
è·å–æ¨¡å¼

If less than $40\%$ of last yearâ€™s buyers will buy this year, then the focus of the business is on new customer acquisition. Loyalty programs arenâ€™t good long-term investments for this kind of business. Kevin says that $70\%$ of e-commerce businesses fall into this category when theyâ€™re mature. Vendors of scuba or rock climbing equipment might be a great example of this: many of their customers buy gear once, and donâ€™t get so hooked on the hobby that they need to upgrade. Thatâ€™s not a bad thingâ€”it just dictates marketing strategy. An online vendor of eyewear might put more of its marketing efforts into convincing past buyers to refer others, and less into convincing those buyers to purchase multiple pairs of glasses, for example.

If $40\mathrm{-}60\%$ of last yearâ€™s buyers will buy this year, then the company will grow with a mix of new customers and returning customers. If $60\%$ or more of last yearâ€™s buyers will buy something this year, the company needs to focus on loyalty, encouraging loyal clients to buy more frequently. â€¢ A 90-day repurchase rate of $1\%$ to $15\%$ means youâ€™re in acquisition mode.

â€¢ A 90-day repurchase rate of $15\%$ to $30\%$ means youâ€™re in hybrid mode.

# Abandonment  
æ”¾å¼ƒ

Not everyone buys something. At its simplest, abandonment rate is the opposite of conversion rate. But a purchasing process often has several stepsâ€”reviewing items in a shopping cart, providing shipping information, entering billing details, and so on. In some cases, the process may even involve a third-party site: Kickstarter sends users to Amazon to provide their credit card information, and Eventbrite links to PayPal so buyers can pay for tickets.  
å¹¶éæ‰€æœ‰äººéƒ½è´­ä¹°ã€‚æœ€ç®€å•åœ°è¯´ï¼Œæ”¾å¼ƒç‡æ˜¯è½¬åŒ–ç‡çš„åé¢ã€‚ä½†è´­ä¹°è¿‡ç¨‹é€šå¸¸åŒ…å«å¤šä¸ªæ­¥éª¤â€”â€”æŸ¥çœ‹è´­ç‰©è½¦ä¸­çš„å•†å“ã€æä¾›è¿è¾“ä¿¡æ¯ã€è¾“å…¥è´¦å•è¯¦æƒ…ç­‰ç­‰ã€‚åœ¨æŸäº›æƒ…å†µä¸‹ï¼Œè¿™ä¸ªè¿‡ç¨‹ç”šè‡³å¯èƒ½æ¶‰åŠç¬¬ä¸‰æ–¹ç½‘ç«™ï¼šKickstarter å°†ç”¨æˆ·å¼•å¯¼è‡³ Amazon æä¾›ä¿¡ç”¨å¡ä¿¡æ¯ï¼Œè€Œ Eventbrite åˆ™é“¾æ¥åˆ° PayPalï¼Œä»¥ä¾¿ä¹°å®¶è´­ä¹°é—¨ç¥¨ã€‚

The number of people who abandon a funnel at each of these stages is the abandonment rate. Itâ€™s important to analyze it for each step in order to see which parts of the process are hurting you the most. In some cases, this may be a particular form fieldâ€”for example, asking people for their nationality could be alienating buyers. Tools like ClickTale perform abandonment analysis within the form itself, making it easier to pinpoint bottlenecks in the conversion process where youâ€™re losing customers.

# Cost of Customer Acquisition  
å®¢æˆ·è·å–æˆæœ¬

Once you know you can extract money from visitors, youâ€™ll want to drive traffic to the site. You may be using advertising, social media outreach, mailing lists, or affiliates. Whatever the case, youâ€™re going to need to add it up. E-commerce sites are simple math: make more from selling things than it costs you to find buyers and deliver the goods.

# Revenue Per Customer  
æ¯å®¢æˆ·æ”¶å…¥

Revenue per customer (or lifetime value) is important for all types of e-commerce businesses, regardless of whether youâ€™re focused on new customer acquisition or loyalty (or both). Even if your business doesnâ€™t engender loyalty (because youâ€™re selling something thatâ€™s infrequently purchased), you want to maximize revenue per customer; you do so by increasing shopping cart size and conversion while reducing abandonment. Revenue per customer is really an aggregate metric of other key numbers, and represents a good, single measure of your e-commerce businessâ€™s health.

# Analytics Lessons Learned  
åˆ†æå­¦ç»éªŒæ•™è®­

Page optimization is important. But be sure youâ€™re optimizing the right metric. You donâ€™t just want a high conversion rateâ€”though thatâ€™s good. You want high revenue per visitor, or high customer lifetime value (CLV), because thatâ€™s whatâ€™s really driving your business model.

# Keywords and Search Terms  
å…³é”®è¯å’Œæœç´¢è¯

Most people find products by searching for them, whether thatâ€™s in a web browser, on a search engine, or within a site. In each case, you want to know which keywords drive traffic that turns into money.  
å¤§å¤šæ•°äººé€šè¿‡æœç´¢æ¥æ‰¾åˆ°äº§å“ï¼Œæ— è®ºæ˜¯åœ¨ç½‘ç»œæµè§ˆå™¨ã€æœç´¢å¼•æ“è¿˜æ˜¯ç½‘ç«™å†…éƒ¨ã€‚åœ¨ä»»ä½•æƒ…å†µä¸‹ï¼Œä½ éƒ½æƒ³çŸ¥é“å“ªäº›å…³é”®è¯èƒ½å¸¦æ¥è½¬åŒ–ä¸ºé‡‘é’±çš„æµé‡ã€‚

These metrics follow a natural, logical order. Consider the customerâ€™s lifecycle: the company acquires a user through viral or paid marketing. Unfortunately, thatâ€™s not always possible. Thereâ€™s no way to measure conversion rates if there are no users to convert. You canâ€™t quantify virality if no paid customers are inviting new users. And you probably canâ€™t measure stickiness for just a few people if the service requires a critical mass of users to be useful. This means you have to know where the risk is, but focus, in the right order, on just enough optimization to get the business to a place where that risk can be quantified and understood.

The company will, of course, need some amount of conversion (and therefore some amount of attention), but only enough to test stickiness. Thereâ€™s a natural progression of metrics that matter for a business that change over time as the business evolves. The metrics start by tracking questions like â€œDoes anyone care about this at all?â€ and then get more sophisticated, asking questions like â€œCan this business actually scale?â€ As you start to look at more sophisticated metrics, you may realize your business model is fundamentally flawed and unsustainable. The ultimate metric for engagement is daily use. How many of your customers use your product on a daily basis? Itâ€™s also hard to demonstrate enough value, quickly enough, to keep people from churning. Habits are hard to formâ€”and with any new product, youâ€™re creating new habits, which you want to do as quickly and intensely as possible.

If youâ€™re building something genuinely disruptive, you need to consider the technology adoption lifecycle, from early to mainstream. In the first stages of your company, you typically have a small, devoted, unreasonably passionate following. This happens because new products initially appeal only to early adopters comfortable with change, or to that segment of the market so desperate for your solution that itâ€™s willing to tolerate something thatâ€™s still rough around the edges. Those early adopters will be vocal, but beware. Their needs might not reflect those of the bigger, more lucrative mainstream. Google Wave attracted a flurry of early attention, but failed to achieve mainstream interest despite its powerful, flexible feature set.

When measuring engagement, donâ€™t just look at a coarse metric like visit frequency. Look for usage patterns throughout your application. For example, itâ€™s interesting to know that people log in three times per week, but what are they actually doing inside your application? What if theyâ€™re only spending a few minutes each time? Is that good or bad? Are there specific features theyâ€™re using versus others? Is there one feature that they always use, and are there others they never touch? Did they return of their own accord, or in response to an email?

â€¢ To find ways you might improve things, segment users who do what you want from those who donâ€™t, and identify ways in which theyâ€™re different. Do the engaged users all live in the same city? Do all users who eventually become loyal contributors learn about you from one social network? Are the users who successfully invite friends all under 30 years old? If you find a concentration of desirable behavior in one segment, you can then target it. â€¢ To decide whether a change worked, test the change on a subset of your users and compare that subsetâ€™s results to others. If you put in a new reporting feature, reveal it to half of your users, and see if more of them stick around for several months. If you canâ€™t test features in this way without falloutâ€”the customers who didnâ€™t get the new feature might get angryâ€”then at the very least, compare the cohort of users who joined after the feature was added to those who came before.

# Churn  
ç”¨æˆ·æµå¤±

Churn is the percentage of people who abandon your service over time. This can be measured weekly, monthly, quarterly, etc., but you should pick a timespan for all your metrics and stick to it in order to make comparing them easier. In a freemium or free-trial business model, you have both users (not paid) and customers (paid), and you should track churn for both groups separately. While churn might seem like a simple metric, there are a number of complications that can make it misleading, particularly for companies that have a highly variable growth rate.

Unpaid users â€œchurnâ€ by cancelling their accounts or simply not coming back; paid users churn by cancelling their accounts, stopping their payments, or reverting to an unpaid version. We recommend defining an inactive user as someone who hasnâ€™t logged in within 90 days (or less). At that point, theyâ€™ve churned out; in an always-connected world, 90 days is an eternity.

# Churn Complications  
æµå¤±ç‡å¤æ‚é—®é¢˜

Noble explains that because the number of churns in a particular period is affected by the entire period, but the number of customers at the beginning of a period is a moment-in-time snapshot, calculating churn in this simple manner can give misleading results in startups where growth is varied or unusually fast. In other words, churn isnâ€™t normalized for behavior and sizeâ€”you can get different churn rates for the same kind of user behavior if youâ€™re not careful.  
Noble è§£é‡Šè¯´ï¼Œå› ä¸ºåœ¨ç‰¹å®šæ—¶æœŸå†…çš„æµå¤±å®¢æˆ·æ•°é‡å—åˆ°æ•´ä¸ªæ—¶æœŸçš„å½±å“ï¼Œä½†æœŸåˆçš„å®¢æˆ·æ•°é‡åªæ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªç¬é—´çš„å¿«ç…§ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥ä»¥è¿™ç§ç®€å•çš„æ–¹å¼è®¡ç®—æµå¤±ç‡å¯èƒ½ä¼šåœ¨å¢é•¿å¤šå˜æˆ–å¼‚å¸¸å¿«é€Ÿçš„æ–°åˆ›ä¼ä¸šä¸­ç»™å‡ºè¯¯å¯¼æ€§çš„ç»“æœã€‚æ¢å¥è¯è¯´ï¼Œæµå¤±ç‡å¹¶æ²¡æœ‰æ ¹æ®è¡Œä¸ºå’Œè§„æ¨¡è¿›è¡Œæ ‡å‡†åŒ–â€”â€”å¦‚æœä½ ä¸å°å¿ƒï¼Œå¯¹äºåŒä¸€ç§ç”¨æˆ·è¡Œä¸ºå¯èƒ½ä¼šå¾—åˆ°ä¸åŒçš„æµå¤±ç‡ã€‚

To fix this, you need to calculate churn in a less simple, but more accurate, way: average out the number of customers in the period youâ€™re analyzing, so youâ€™re not just looking at how many you had at the beginning:  
è¦è§£å†³è¿™ä¸ªé—®é¢˜ï¼Œä½ éœ€è¦ç”¨ä¸€ç§æ›´å¤æ‚ä½†æ›´å‡†ç¡®çš„æ–¹å¼æ¥è®¡ç®—æµå¤±ç‡ï¼šå¹³å‡åˆ†ææœŸé—´å†…çš„å®¢æˆ·æ•°é‡ï¼Œè¿™æ ·ä½ å°±ä¸ä¼šåªçœ‹åˆ†æå¼€å§‹æ—¶çš„å®¢æˆ·æ•°é‡ï¼š

(Number of churns during period)  
ï¼ˆæœŸé—´å†…çš„æµå¤±æ•°é‡ï¼‰

This spreads out the total number of customers across the period, which is better, but it still presents a problem if things are growing quickly. If you have 100 customers at the start of the month, and 10,000 at the end, this formula assumes you have 5,050 customers in the middle of the monthâ€” which you donâ€™t, if youâ€™re on a hockey stick. Most of your new customers come in the later part of the month, so an average wonâ€™t work. Whatâ€™s more, most of your churns will, too.  
è¿™å°†å®¢æˆ·æ€»æ•°åˆ†å¸ƒåœ¨æœŸé—´å†…ï¼Œè¿™æ›´å¥½ï¼Œä½†å¦‚æœå¢é•¿å¾ˆå¿«ï¼Œä»ç„¶å­˜åœ¨é—®é¢˜ã€‚å¦‚æœä½ åœ¨æœˆåˆæœ‰ 100 åå®¢æˆ·ï¼Œæœˆæœ«æœ‰ 10,000 åå®¢æˆ·ï¼Œè¿™ä¸ªå…¬å¼å‡è®¾ä½ åœ¨æœˆä¸­æ‹¥æœ‰ 5,050 åå®¢æˆ·â€”â€”å¦‚æœä½ å¤„äºå†°çƒæ†å‹å¢é•¿ï¼Œè¿™æ˜¯ä¸æ­£ç¡®çš„ã€‚ä½ å¤§éƒ¨åˆ†çš„æ–°å®¢æˆ·éƒ½æ˜¯åœ¨æœˆæœ«åŠ å…¥çš„ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥å¹³å‡æ•°è¡Œä¸é€šã€‚æ­¤å¤–ï¼Œä½ å¤§éƒ¨åˆ†çš„æµå¤±å®¢æˆ·ä¹Ÿéƒ½æ˜¯åœ¨æœˆæœ«ã€‚

Worse: if youâ€™re counting churns as â€œsomeone who hasnâ€™t come back in 30 days,â€ then youâ€™re comparing last monthâ€™s losses to this monthâ€™s gains, which is even more dangerous, because youâ€™re looking at a lagging indicator (last monthâ€™s bad news). So by the time you find out something is wrong, itâ€™ll be next month.  
æ›´ç³Ÿçš„æ˜¯ï¼šå¦‚æœä½ å°†æµå¤±å®¢æˆ·å®šä¹‰ä¸ºâ€œ30 å¤©å†…æ²¡æœ‰å›æ¥çš„äººâ€ï¼Œé‚£ä¹ˆä½ å°†ä¸Šä¸ªæœˆçš„æŸå¤±ä¸è¿™ä¸ªæœˆçš„å¢é•¿è¿›è¡Œæ¯”è¾ƒï¼Œè¿™æ›´åŠ å±é™©ï¼Œå› ä¸ºä½ æ˜¯åœ¨çœ‹æ»åæŒ‡æ ‡ï¼ˆä¸Šä¸ªæœˆçš„åæ¶ˆæ¯ï¼‰ã€‚æ‰€ä»¥ç­‰ä½ å‘ç°é—®é¢˜æ—¶ï¼Œå·²ç»åˆ°ä¸‹ä¸ªæœˆäº†ã€‚

Ultimately, the math gets really complex. There are two ways to simplify it. The first is to measure churn by cohort, so youâ€™re comparing new to churned users based on when they first became users. The second way is really, really simple, which is why we like it: measure churn each day. The shorter the time period you measure, the less that changes during that specific period will distort things.

# Analytics Lessons Learned  
åˆ†æå­¦ç»éªŒæ•™è®­

Just because SaaS is a recurring service doesnâ€™t mean it needs to be priced that way. If your product is ephemeralâ€”like a transient job postingâ€”it might be better to offer more transactional pricing. Pricing is a tricky beast. You need to test different price points qualitatively (by getting feedback from customers) and quantitatively. Donâ€™t assume a low price is the answer; customers might not attribute enough value to your offering. And remember that everything, including price, makes up the â€œproductâ€ youâ€™re offering.

# Wrinkles: Freemium, Tiers, and Other Pricing Models  
çš±çº¹ï¼šå…è´¹å¢å€¼ã€åˆ†å±‚å’Œå…¶ä»–å®šä»·æ¨¡å¼

In a SaaS model, most of the complexity comes from two things: the promotional approach you choose, and pricing tiers.  
åœ¨ SaaS æ¨¡å¼ä¸­ï¼Œå¤æ‚æ€§ä¸»è¦æ¥è‡ªä¸¤ä¸ªæ–¹é¢ï¼šä½ é€‰æ‹©çš„æ¨å¹¿æ–¹å¼ä»¥åŠå®šä»·å±‚çº§ã€‚

As weâ€™ve seen, some SaaS companies use a freemium model to convince people to use the service, and then make money when those users exceed some kind of cap. A second approach is a free trial, which converts to a paid subscription if the customer doesnâ€™t explicitly cancel after a certain time. A third approach is paid-only. There are others. Each has its benefits and drawbacksâ€”paid-only controls cost, is more predictable, and gives you an immediate idea of whether your offering is valuable; freemium allows you to learn how people are using your service and builds goodwill. The difference between these user groups can complicate analysis.

The second wrinkle comes from how you tier pricing. Since different customers have different levels of consumption, the price they pay may change over time. This means youâ€™re constantly trying to upsell users to bigger tiers, and predicting growth adds to the dimensions of a model, making it harder to predict and explain your business.

# Average Revenue Per User  
æ¯ç”¨æˆ·å¹³å‡æ”¶å…¥

Mobile app developers are constantly finding ingenious ways to monetize their applications. These developers focus on the average revenue per user (ARPU) on a monthly or lifetime basis. Many game developers instrument their applications heavily themselves, since there isnâ€™t a dominant, open way to collect data from applications easily.

If youâ€™re making a game, you donâ€™t just care about revenue. Youâ€™re walking a fine line between the compelling content and addictive gameplay that makes things fun and the in-game purchases that bring in money. Avoiding the â€œmoney grabâ€ that turns players off is hard: you need to keep users coming back and inviting their friends while still extracting a pound of flesh each month (or at least a few dollars!). As a result, in addition to ARPU, some metrics relate to playability (ensuring the game is neither too hard nor too easy, and that players donâ€™t get stuck) and player engagement.

ARPU is simply the revenue youâ€™ve made, divided by the number of active users or players you have. If you inflate the number of active players to make yourself look good, youâ€™ll reduce the ARPU, so this metric forces you to draw a realistic line in the sand about what â€œengagedâ€ means. Typically, ARPU is calculated on a monthly period.

The business model for the company hinges on these numbers. # Percentage of Users Who Pay  
æ”¯ä»˜ç”¨æˆ·ç™¾åˆ†æ¯”

There are some players who simply wonâ€™t spend money in a game. And there are others (often referred to as â€œwhalesâ€) who will spend literally thousands of dollars to gain the upper hand in a game they love. Knowing the difference between the twoâ€”and finding ways to make more users purchase things within the applicationâ€”is the key to a successfully monetized free mobile application.  
æœ‰äº›ç©å®¶æ ¹æœ¬ä¸ä¼šåœ¨æ¸¸æˆä¸­èŠ±é’±ã€‚è€Œå¦ä¸€äº›ç©å®¶ï¼ˆé€šå¸¸è¢«ç§°ä¸ºâ€œé²¸é±¼â€ï¼‰åˆ™æ„¿æ„èŠ±æ•°åƒç¾å…ƒæ¥åœ¨ä»–ä»¬å–œçˆ±çš„æ¸¸æˆä¸­è·å¾—ä¼˜åŠ¿ã€‚äº†è§£è¿™ä¸¤è€…ä¹‹é—´çš„åŒºåˆ«ï¼Œå¹¶æ‰¾åˆ°è®©æ›´å¤šç”¨æˆ·åœ¨åº”ç”¨å†…è´­ä¹°ä¸œè¥¿çš„æ–¹æ³•ï¼Œæ˜¯æˆåŠŸå®ç°å…è´¹ç§»åŠ¨åº”ç”¨ç›ˆåˆ©çš„å…³é”®ã€‚

The most basic metric here is the percentage of users who pay something. Beyond this basic metric, you want to do segmentation and cohort analysis. If, for example, you know that a particular ad campaign brought in users who were more likely to make in-game purchases, you should be running more campaigns like that. You also need to be sophisticated in terms of what you market to users in-game: whales are more likely to make bigger in-app purchases, whereas users who havenâ€™t bought anything yet should be offered something inexpensive to start.

Measuring your ARPU gives you a good idea of how much paying users are spending. Convincing an already-paying user to pay more may not have a significant impact on your ARPU because most users wonâ€™t pay, but it could absolutely move the needle on revenue in a significant way. Treat your paying users as a separate customer base and track their behavior, churn, and revenue separately from your nonpaying ones.

Weâ€™ve looked at churn in detail in Chapter 9. Itâ€™s also a critical metric for mobile applications. Keith Katz, co-founder of Execution Labs, a game development accelerator, and former Vice President of Monetization for OpenFeint, recommends looking at churn in specific time periods:

Track churn at 1 day, 1 week, and 1 month, because users leave at different times for different reasons. After one day it could be you have a lousy tutorial or just arenâ€™t hooking users. After a week it could be that your game isnâ€™t â€œdeep enough,â€ and after a month it could be poor update planning.

German game developer Wooga is a master of metrics. The company is building a formula for successful social games thatâ€™s completely driven by numbers. The company has over 32 million active monthly users from 231 countries, and over 7 million daily users. In a 2012 Wired article, founder Jens Begemann shared his companyâ€™s approach.\*

Wooga iterates constantly and releases updates on a weekly basis. It picks a key metric to focus on for an updateâ€”retention, for exampleâ€” and identifies a number of tactics to try to improve it. When the update is released, it measures the changes rigorously and adapts from there. All told, Jens reviews 128 data points on a daily basis. If he sees something that doesnâ€™t make sense to him, he sends that to the product teams. Itâ€™s up to the product people at that point to home in on the number in question and figure out whatâ€™s going on, and how to make it better.

One of the factors that can complicate this model is the monetization approach. As weâ€™ve seen, there are a wide variety of ways in which companies monetize their mobile applications. Some advertising consists of in-app videos; in other cases, it can be a â€œpromoted downloadâ€ where the user is encouraged to try out another app. When this happens, the user leaves the current applicationâ€”which can increase churn, reduce engagement, and hamper the experience.

# Model Four: Media Site  
æ¨¡å‹å››ï¼šåª’ä½“ç½‘ç«™

Advertising pays for the Internet. Itâ€™s so easy to insert advertising into online content that for many companies, ad-based monetization is a fallback revenue source, which subsidizes a cheaply priced game or helps pay for the cost of operating a freemium product. Many websites rely on advertising to pay the bills, but few do it well. Those that do are generally content-focused, trying to attract repeat visitors who will spend a decent amount of time on the site and view many pages.  
å¹¿å‘Šæ”¯æ’‘ç€äº’è”ç½‘ã€‚å°†å¹¿å‘Šæ’å…¥åœ¨çº¿å†…å®¹éå¸¸å®¹æ˜“ï¼Œå¯¹äºè®¸å¤šå…¬å¸æ¥è¯´ï¼ŒåŸºäºå¹¿å‘Šçš„ç›ˆåˆ©æ˜¯ä¸€ç§å¤‡é€‰æ”¶å…¥æ¥æºï¼Œå®ƒå¯ä»¥è¡¥è´´ä»·æ ¼ä½å»‰çš„æ¸¸æˆï¼Œæˆ–è€…å¸®åŠ©æ”¯ä»˜å…è´¹å¢å€¼äº§å“çš„è¿è¥æˆæœ¬ã€‚è®¸å¤šç½‘ç«™ä¾èµ–å¹¿å‘Šæ¥ç»´æŒè¿è¥ï¼Œä½†å¾ˆå°‘èƒ½åšå¥½ã€‚é‚£äº›åšå¾—å¥½çš„é€šå¸¸æ˜¯å†…å®¹å¯¼å‘çš„ï¼Œè¯•å›¾å¸å¼•ä¼šèŠ±è´¹ç›¸å½“æ—¶é—´åœ¨ç½‘ç«™ä¸Šå¹¶æµè§ˆè®¸å¤šé¡µé¢çš„å›å¤´å®¢ã€‚

If your business model most closely resembles a media site, then your primary focus is sharing advertisersâ€™ messages with viewers, and getting paid for impressions, click-throughs, or sales. Googleâ€™s search engine, CNETâ€™s home page, and CNNâ€™s website are all media sites.

Ad revenue comes in a variety of formats. Some sites make money when they display banners or have sponsorship agreements. Sometimes revenue is tied to the number of clicks on ads or to a kickback from affiliates. Sometimes itâ€™s simply display advertising shown each time thereâ€™s an engagement with a visitor.

In this example, a website launches in January, and gets 3,000 unique visitors that month. Each month, it adds a certain number of unique firsttime visitors to the site, but it also loses some visitors. You can calculate the churn by subtracting the number of unique first-time visitors from the change over the previous monthâ€”the new visitors are â€œmaking upâ€ the last monthâ€™s loss.

# PATTERN Performance and the Sessions-to-Clicks Ratio  
æ¨¡å¼æ€§èƒ½å’Œä¼šè¯åˆ°ç‚¹å‡»æ¯”ç‡

One other factor to consider is the sessions-to-clicks ratio. Every website loses a certain number of visitors before they ever come to the site. For every 100 web searches that link to you and get clicked, roughly 95 will actually land on your site. Basically, this says that five of those people hit the back button, or decide your site is taking too long to load, or change their mind about visiting.  
å¦ä¸€ä¸ªéœ€è¦è€ƒè™‘çš„å› ç´ æ˜¯ä¼šè¯åˆ°ç‚¹å‡»çš„æ¯”ç‡ã€‚æ¯ä¸ªç½‘ç«™åœ¨è®¿å®¢å®é™…åˆ°è¾¾ä¹‹å‰éƒ½ä¼šå¤±å»ä¸€å®šæ•°é‡çš„è®¿å®¢ã€‚å¯¹äºæ¯ 100 ä¸ªé“¾æ¥åˆ°ä½ çš„ç½‘ç«™å¹¶ç‚¹å‡»çš„ç½‘é¡µæœç´¢ï¼Œå¤§çº¦æœ‰ 95 ä¸ªä¼šå®é™…åˆ°è¾¾ä½ çš„ç½‘ç«™ã€‚åŸºæœ¬ä¸Šï¼Œè¿™æ„å‘³ç€æœ‰äº”ä¸ªäººç‚¹å‡»äº†åé€€æŒ‰é’®ï¼Œæˆ–è€…è®¤ä¸ºä½ çš„ç½‘ç«™åŠ è½½å¤ªæ…¢ï¼Œæˆ–è€…æ”¹å˜äº†è®¿é—®çš„å¿µå¤´ã€‚

The ratio of sessions (on your site) to clicks (from search links or referring links) is an indicator of web performance and reliability. Shopzillaâ€™s Jody Mulkey and Phillip Dixon did a detailed analysis of the impact of performance improvement on the sessions-to-clicks ratio when the company rebuilt its site to make it load quickly and reliably.\* Ultimately, the makeover landed the site $3\%$ more visitors. But within a short while, the site slowed down again as a result of ongoing changes, and the ratio worsened once more. Keeping a site fast is a constant battle.

# Ad Rates  
å¹¿å‘Šè´¹ç‡

The rate advertising networks will pay you for an ad depends on your content and the going rate for a particular search term or keyword. For a straight-up media site, the ad rate is driven by the topic of your site and the content you publish. For a social network, the demographics of your audience drive ad rates. Visitor demographics will become increasingly important as social platforms like Facebook introduce third-party-placed advertising based on demographic segmentsâ€”youâ€™ll get paid based on who your visitors are rather than what your site contains.

# Content/Advertising Trade-of  
å†…å®¹/å¹¿å‘Šæƒè¡¡

The big decision any media site makes is how to pay the bills without selling out. This manifests itself in two ways. First, ad space: too many ads leads to lousy content and reduced visitor loyalty. Second, content: if your content is written to attract lucrative ad keywords, itâ€™ll feel forced and seem like a paid promotion.

The variety of business relationships in online media can make finding the right key performance indicator (KPI) complex. Here are four examples of the kinds of complexity you need to watch out for.

Hidden affiliate models  
éšè—çš„è”ç›Ÿæ¨¡å¼

Pinterest, an online pinboard of images, used to rewrite URLs for pictures of products its users had uploaded using a tool called Skimlinks. But as the site grew, its affiliate revenue quickly outstripped that of other big networks,\* and it was called out for the practice.â€   
Pinterest æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªåœ¨çº¿å›¾ç‰‡å¢™ï¼Œå®ƒä½¿ç”¨ä¸€ä¸ªåä¸º Skimlinks çš„å·¥å…·æ¥é‡å†™ç”¨æˆ·ä¸Šä¼ çš„äº§å“å›¾ç‰‡çš„ URLã€‚ä½†éšç€ç½‘ç«™çš„å¢é•¿ï¼Œå…¶è”ç›Ÿæ”¶å…¥è¿…é€Ÿè¶…è¿‡äº†å…¶ä»–å¤§å‹ç½‘ç»œ\*ï¼Œå› æ­¤å®ƒå› è¿™ç§åšæ³•è€Œå—åˆ°æŒ‡è´£ã€‚â€ 

Pinterest was able to monetize traffic quickly with this strategy, and cared not only about how many people contributed content (a usergenerated content, or UGC, metric), but also about the likelihood that someone would click on a picture and in turn make a purchase. Affiliate rewriting is a good way to monetize user-generated content without adsâ€”effectively turning everything thatâ€™s posted into an adâ€”but complicates business modeling, and can backfire.

# Background noise  
èƒŒæ™¯å™ªéŸ³

In one test, blank ads bearing no information had a click-through rate of roughly $0.08\%$ â€”comparable to that of some paid campaigns.â€¡ The ads invited those whoâ€™d clicked to explain why they did so; respondents were evenly divided between simple curiosity and accidental clicking. If your ads are getting revenues that are hardly better than the background noise a blank ad would get, you need to find out why.

# Ad blockers  
å¹¿å‘Šæ‹¦æˆªå™¨

Technical users sometimes install ad-blocking software in their browsers that blocks ads from known ad-serving companies. This reduces your inventory, and can mess with your analytics. Reddit actually runs some ads containing funny content, mini-games, or messages thanking visitors for not blocking ads.

# Paywalls  
ä»˜è´¹å¢™

Unsatisfied with the revenues from online advertising, some media sites run paywalls that charge users to access content. The paywall model runs the spectrum from voluntary donations (usually in the form of a pop up when the visitor first arrives) to fully paid sites where content is accessible only for a recurring fee.

Some media sites adopt a middle ground where visitors can access a quota of articles each month, as shown in Figure 11-2, but must pay to see more than this limit. Such sites are trying to strike a balance between â€œreferredâ€ content (e.g., an article mentioned on Twitter, which might generate ad revenue) and â€œsubscribedâ€ content (where the site is a userâ€™s primary daily news source).

# Key Takeaways  
å…³é”®è¦ç‚¹

â€¢ For media sites, ad revenue is everythingâ€”but advertising may include displays, pay-per-view, pay-per-click, and affiliate models, so tracking revenues is complex.

# Model Five: User-Generated Content  
æ¨¡å‹äº”ï¼šç”¨æˆ·ç”Ÿæˆå†…å®¹

You might think that Facebook, reddit, and Twitter are media sites, and youâ€™d be right: they make their money from advertising. But their primary goal is rallying an engaged community that creates content. Similarly focused sites like Wikipedia make their money from other sources, such as donations.

We call these businesses user-generated content (UGC) sites. They deserve their own business model because their primary concern is the growth of an engaged community that creates content; without user activity, the sites stop functioning entirely. If youâ€™ve decided that youâ€™re in the UGC business, then this chapter explains what metrics youâ€™ll need to track.

In this model, youâ€™re focused on the creation of good content, which means not only posts and uploads but also votes, comments, spam flagging, and other valuable activity. UGC is about the amount of good content versus bad, and the percentage of users who are lurkers versus creators. This is anÂ  engagement funnel,\* similar to the traditional conversion funnels of an e-commerce modelâ€”only instead of moving prospects toward buying, youâ€™re constantly trying to move your user population to higher and higher levels of engagement, turning lurkers into voters, voters into commenters, and so on.

Wikipedia is an example of a UGC siteâ€”good, reliable, well-referenced content helps the site; flame wars or frequent edits between two battling contributors are bad for it. Just as an e-commerce site creates a funnel out of the steps through which a buyer must proceed, a UGC site measures the percentage of users who behave in certain ways. Revenue often comes from advertising or donations, but itâ€™s incidental to the core business of engaging users.

Consider a social network focused on link sharing, such as reddit. Anyone can read content and share it using social buttons on the site. Once a user has an account, she can vote content up or down, comment on content, or post content of her own. She can create her own group discussion around a topic. And she can use her account to message other users privately.

The tiers of engagement create a natural funnel, from the completely disengaged, fly-by visitors who come just once, to the hardcore. A UGC site is successful when its visitors become regulars. As weâ€™ve seen with SaaS churn, we look at recency to understand thisâ€”that is, when was the last time someone came back to the site? One quick way to measure this is the day-to-week ratio: how many of todayâ€™s visitors were here earlier in the week? Itâ€™s an indicator of whether people are returning on a regular basis, even if users donâ€™t create an account.

Early on, UGC sites need to solve a chicken-and-egg problem. They need content to draw in users, and users to create content. Sometimes, this content can be seeded from elsewhere: Wikimedia was originally going to be a site written by experts, but eventually pivoted to a community-edited modelâ€”it overcame the chicken-and-egg issue by having content in place at the start.

The rate of content creation and the rate of enrollment matter a lot at the outset. Later, the question becomes whether good content is rising to the top, and whether people are commenting on itâ€”signs that your user base cares about the discussion and is building a community.

# Engagement Funnel Changes  
å‚ä¸åº¦æ¼æ–—å˜åŒ–

On reddit, there are several tiers of engagement: urking, voting, commenting, subscribing to a subreddit, submitting links, and creating subreddits. Each tier represents a degree of involvement and content generation by a user, and each type of user represents a different business value to the company. Every UGC site has a similar funnel, though the steps may be different.  
åœ¨ Reddit ä¸Šï¼Œå‚ä¸åº¦æœ‰å‡ ä¸ªå±‚æ¬¡ï¼šæµè§ˆã€æŠ•ç¥¨ã€è¯„è®ºã€è®¢é˜…å­ç‰ˆå—ã€æäº¤é“¾æ¥å’Œåˆ›å»ºå­ç‰ˆå—ã€‚æ¯ä¸ªå±‚æ¬¡ä»£è¡¨ç”¨æˆ·å‚ä¸å’Œå†…å®¹ç”Ÿæˆçš„ç¨‹åº¦ï¼Œæ¯ç§ç±»å‹çš„ç”¨æˆ·å¯¹å…¬å¸æ¥è¯´ä»£è¡¨ä¸åŒçš„å•†ä¸šä»·å€¼ã€‚æ¯ä¸ª UGC ç½‘ç«™éƒ½æœ‰ä¸€ä¸ªç±»ä¼¼çš„æ¼æ–—ï¼Œå°½ç®¡æ­¥éª¤å¯èƒ½ä¸åŒã€‚

The steps in the funnel arenâ€™t mutually exclusiveâ€”someone can comment without voting, for exampleâ€”but these steps should be arranged in an order of increasing value to your business model as a user moves down the funnel. In other words, if someone who posts content is â€œbetterâ€ for you than someone who simply shares a story, sheâ€™s in a later tier of the funnel. The key is to move as many users into the more lucrative tiers as possible (making more content and better selection of content that will be popular).

This is very similar to the SaaS upselling model: for a given cohort of users, how long does it take them to move to a more valuable stage in the engagement funnel? We used to design exclusively for the Web. In recent years, designers rallied around portable devices with cries of â€œdesign for mobileâ€ or â€œmobile first.â€ But thereâ€™s good reason to think that the future of applications isnâ€™t mobilityâ€”itâ€™s notification.

# Wrinkles: Passive Content Creation  
çš±çº¹ï¼šè¢«åŠ¨å†…å®¹åˆ›ä½œ

Just as notifications happen in the background but are in many ways the new foreground interface, so too does content creation often happen stealthily. Google has been able to pack its social network, Google $^+$ , with information and updates across its user base simply by enabling background features like Latitude and image uploads, and by linking to external sites based on your profile.  
å°±åƒé€šçŸ¥åœ¨åå°å‘ç”Ÿä½†åœ¨å¾ˆå¤šæ–¹é¢æ˜¯æ–°å‰æ™¯ç•Œé¢ä¸€æ ·ï¼Œå†…å®¹åˆ›ä½œä¹Ÿå¸¸å¸¸å·å·è¿›è¡Œã€‚è°·æ­Œé€šè¿‡å¯ç”¨åƒ Latitude å’Œå›¾ç‰‡ä¸Šä¼ è¿™æ ·çš„åå°åŠŸèƒ½ï¼Œå¹¶åŸºäºä½ çš„ä¸ªäººèµ„æ–™é“¾æ¥åˆ°å¤–éƒ¨ç½‘ç«™ï¼Œä»…ä»…å°±èƒ½åœ¨å…¶ç”¨æˆ·ç¾¤ä¸­æ‰“åŒ…å…¶ç¤¾äº¤ç½‘ç»œ Google+çš„ä¿¡æ¯å’Œæ›´æ–°ã€‚

As more and more mobile devices become sensors that track our health, our location, our purchases, and our habits, weâ€™ll see a split into active content generation (sharing a link, writing a post) and passive content generation (automatically populating a timeline with our actions; helping the system learn from our clickstream). This shift gives a huge advantage to those who make the tools for collecting dataâ€”mobile device makers, payment companies, and so on.  
éšç€è¶Šæ¥è¶Šå¤šçš„ç§»åŠ¨è®¾å¤‡æˆä¸ºè·Ÿè¸ªæˆ‘ä»¬å¥åº·ã€ä½ç½®ã€è´­ä¹°å’Œä¹ æƒ¯çš„ä¼ æ„Ÿå™¨ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å°†çœ‹åˆ°åˆ†ä¸ºä¸»åŠ¨å†…å®¹ç”Ÿæˆï¼ˆåˆ†äº«é“¾æ¥ã€å†™å¸–å­ï¼‰å’Œè¢«åŠ¨å†…å®¹ç”Ÿæˆï¼ˆè‡ªåŠ¨ç”¨æˆ‘ä»¬çš„è¡Œä¸ºå¡«å……æ—¶é—´çº¿ï¼›å¸®åŠ©ç³»ç»Ÿä»æˆ‘ä»¬çš„ç‚¹å‡»æµä¸­å­¦ä¹ ï¼‰çš„åˆ†åŒ–ã€‚è¿™ç§è½¬å˜ç»™é‚£äº›åˆ¶ä½œæ”¶é›†æ•°æ®å·¥å…·çš„äººå¸¦æ¥äº†å·¨å¤§ä¼˜åŠ¿â€”â€”ç§»åŠ¨è®¾å¤‡åˆ¶é€ å•†ã€æ”¯ä»˜å…¬å¸ç­‰ç­‰ã€‚

Consider three changes on the horizon: ambient check-ins, in which your smart device registers changes in location and shares them; digital wallets designed to store loyalty, ticket, and membership data; and near-field communications technology that make it possible to share information or pay by bumping your device against something. Two-sided marketplaces are a variation on e-commerce sites, but theyâ€™re different enough to warrant a separate discussion. If, after reading Chapter 7, youâ€™ve concluded that youâ€™re running this kind of company, hereâ€™s what you need to know.

In this model, the company makes money when a buyer and seller come together to complete a transaction. All of these examples include a shared inventory model and two stakeholdersâ€”buyers and sellers, creators and supporters, prospective partners,\* or hotels and travellers. Two-sided marketplaces face a unique problem: they have to attract both buyers and sellers. That looks like twice as much work. Start with the minimum marketplace that proves you have demand, supply, and a desire for buyers and sellers to transact. Then find ways of making money from that activity. The metrics you track will depend on transaction size, frequency, and other unique characteristics of the business. But the fundamentals are the same: revenue from transactions.

Imagine youâ€™re launching a two-sided marketplace for secondhand game consoles. Those with a console to sell can list it, and those looking for a console to buy can browse by a variety of criteria. The transactions are handled through PayPal, and you retain a portion of the proceeds above a minimum amount.

Because youâ€™re not a vendor of consoles yourself, you need to find a way to produce either an inventory of consoles, or a large group of customers. You need to pick which side of the market youâ€™re going to â€œseed.â€

If you want to seed the seller side, you might crawl Craigslist and approach console owners to see if they have inventory, encouraging them to list items. If you want to seed the buyer side, you might set up a forum for nostalgic game players, bringing them together and inviting them from social sites.

You could create an artificial inventory by selling consoles to start with, and then gradually adding inventory from others. Car-service provider Uber overcame the chicken-and-egg problem in new markets by simply buying up available towncars: when the company launched in Seattle, it paid drivers \\30$ an hour to drive passengers around, and switched to a commission model only once it had sufficient demand to make it worthwhile for the drivers. The company created supply.

On the other hand, if you want to seed the buyer side, you probably need to pick something for which you can command an initial inventory, then purchase some; or you might take orders with a promise of fulfilling them later, knowing you have access to that inventory. Amazon, for example, started selling books, which allowed it to streamline its order, search, and logistics processes. Then it could offer a broader range of its own goods. Eventually, with access to many buyers and their search patterns, Amazon became a marketplace for goods from many other suppliers. Salesforce.com created a CRM product, and then created an app exchange ecosystem where third-party developers could sell software to existing customers. With respect to their marketplace offerings, both companies first created demand.

Once youâ€™ve got both sides of the market together, your attention (and analytics) will shift to maximizing the proceeds from the marketâ€”the number of listings, the quality of buyers and sellers, the percentage of searches for which you have at least one item in inventory, the marketplacespecific metrics Josh mentions, and ultimately, the sales volume and resulting revenue. # Buyer and Seller Ratings  
ä¹°å®¶å’Œå–å®¶è¯„åˆ†

Shared marketplaces are often regulated by the users themselvesâ€”users rate one another based on their experience with a transaction. The easiest way to implement this system is to let users flag something thatâ€™s wrong, or that violates the terms of service. Users can also rank one another, and sellers work hard to earn a good reputation when the ratings system works well.

# Wrinkles: Chicken and Egg, Fraud, Keeping the Transaction, and Auctions  
çº ç»“ï¼šé¸¡å…”åŒç¬¼ï¼Œæ¬ºè¯ˆï¼Œç»´æŒäº¤æ˜“ï¼Œä»¥åŠæ‹å–

In the early days of the Web, pundits predicted an open, utopian world of frictionless markets that were transparent and efficient. But as Internet giants like Google, Amazon, and Facebook have shown, parts of the Web are dystopian. Two-sided marketplaces are subject to strong network effectsâ€”the more inventory they have to offer, the more useful they become. A marketplace with no inventory, on the other hand, is useless.

Successful two-sided marketplaces find a way to artificially populate either the buyer or the seller side early on. As a particular niche matures, this network effect means there will be a few dominant playersâ€”as is the case with Airbnb, VRBO, and a few others in the rental property space.

Fraud and trust are the other big issues for such marketplaces. You donâ€™t want to assume responsibility for the delivery of goods or services within your marketplace, but you need to ensure that there are reliable reputation systems. Buyer and seller ratings are one approach to this, but there are other ways. Some dating sites offer guarantees (for example, that they will prosecute if a person turns out to be married).

One more major issue is keeping the transaction within the network. In the case of a sailboat or house marketplace, the transaction may be tens or even hundreds of thousands of dollars. Thatâ€™s not really suitable for a PayPal transaction, and itâ€™s hard to stop â€œleakageâ€â€”buyers and sellers find one another through your marketplace, and then conclude their business without you getting a transaction fee.

There are a number of ways to overcome thisâ€”all of which you should test to see if they work for your product and market. For example, you might:

â€¢ Refer users to an outside agent to conclude the transaction (e.g., a realtor) and monetize the referral.  
â€¢ å¼•å¯¼ç”¨æˆ·åˆ°ä¸€ä¸ªå¤–éƒ¨ä»£ç†äººæ¥å®Œæˆäº¤æ˜“ï¼ˆä¾‹å¦‚ï¼Œæˆ¿åœ°äº§ç»çºªäººï¼‰ï¼Œå¹¶é€šè¿‡æ¨èæ¥è·åˆ©ã€‚

â€¢ å¯¹å–å®¶åˆ—å‡ºçš„å•†å“æ”¶å–æŒ‰å•†å“ä»·å€¼æ¯”ä¾‹è®¡ç®—çš„å›ºå®šè´¹ç”¨ï¼ˆè€Œä¸æ˜¯ç™¾åˆ†æ¯”ï¼‰ã€‚  
â€¢ Monetize something else about the market, such as in-site advertising, shipping services, or favorable placement.  
â€¢ åˆ©ç”¨å¸‚åœºçš„å…¶ä»–æ–¹é¢è¿›è¡Œå˜ç°ï¼Œä¾‹å¦‚ç½‘ç«™å†…å¹¿å‘Šã€è¿è¾“æœåŠ¡æˆ–ä¼˜æƒ ä½ç½®ã€‚  
â€¢ Make it impossible for the two parties to connect or find each otherâ€™s identity until after the transaction is confirmed (as discount travel site Hotwire does).  
â€¢ åœ¨äº¤æ˜“ç¡®è®¤ä¹‹å‰ï¼Œä½¿åŒæ–¹æ— æ³•è¿æ¥æˆ–æ‰¾åˆ°å¯¹æ–¹çš„èº«ä»½ï¼ˆä¾‹å¦‚æŠ˜æ‰£æ—…æ¸¸ç½‘ç«™ Hotwire çš„åšæ³•ï¼‰ã€‚  
â€¢ Offer value-added services (such as purchase insurance or escrow) that encourage participants to keep you in the deal.  
â€¢ æä¾›å¢å€¼æœåŠ¡ï¼ˆä¾‹å¦‚è´­ä¹°ä¿é™©æˆ–æ‰˜ç®¡ï¼‰ï¼Œé¼“åŠ±å‚ä¸è€…å°†ä½ ç•™åœ¨äº¤æ˜“ä¸­ã€‚

Finally, there are auction marketplaces such as eBay where the price of an item isnâ€™t fixed. Two-sided marketplaces are a variant of traditional e-commerce sites. In Ash Mauryaâ€™s framework from earlier in this chapter, he suggests telling a story first to create context around the problem. The risk with a divergent problem interview is that you venture too broadly on too many issues and never get interviewees to focus. Divergent problem interviews run the risk of giving you too many problems, or not enough similar problems, and no clarity on what to do next.

è®¡ç®—åˆ†æ•°

A score of 31 or higher is a good score. Anything under is not. Try scoring all the interviews, and see how many have a good score. This is a decent indication of whether youâ€™re onto something or not with the problems you want to solve. Then ask yourself what makes the good-score interviews different from the bad-score ones. Maybe youâ€™ve identified a market segment, maybe you have better results when you dress well, maybe you shouldnâ€™t do interviews in a coffee shop.Â Everything is an experiment you can learn from.

A top-down analysis starts with a big number and breaks it into smaller parts. A bottom-up one does the reverse. Consider, for example, a restaurant in New York City.

During problem interviews, you want to get a deep understanding of your customer. We mentioned collecting demographics earlier and looking for ways to bucket customers into different groups, but you can take this a step further and gain a lot more insight. You can get inside their heads.

Customers are people. They lead lives. They have kids, they eat too much, they donâ€™t sleep well, they phone in sick, they get bored, they watch too much reality TV. To do this, you need to infiltrate your customerâ€™s daily life. Donâ€™t think of â€œinfiltrateâ€ as a bad word. In order for you to succeed, customers need to use your application; if you want them to do so, you need to slot yourself into their lives in an effortless, seamless way. You should continue doing customer interviews (after the first 10â€“20 or so) and iterate on the questions you ask, dig deeper with people, and learn as much as you can. â€¢ It tests whether you can command the attentionâ€”at scaleâ€”that youâ€™ll need to thrive.

While thereâ€™s no substitute for qualitative data, you can use technology to dramatically improve the efficiency of collecting that data. In the Empathy stage, focus on building tools for getting good feedback quickly from many people. Just because customer development isnâ€™t code doesnâ€™t mean you shouldnâ€™t invest heavily in it.

LikeBright chose Mechanical Turk to reach people at scale, but there are plenty of other tools. Unlike the one-toone interviews youâ€™ve been conducting so far, here you need to automate the task and deal with the inevitable statistical noise.

# Build It Before You Build It (or, How to Validate the Solution)  
åœ¨æ„å»ºä¹‹å‰å…ˆæ„å»ºå®ƒï¼ˆæˆ–è€…ï¼Œå¦‚ä½•éªŒè¯è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆï¼‰

With a validated problem in hand, itâ€™s time to validate the solution.  
åœ¨æ‰‹å¤´æœ‰äº†ç»è¿‡éªŒè¯çš„é—®é¢˜åï¼Œå°±æ˜¯éªŒè¯è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆçš„æ—¶å€™äº†ã€‚

Once again, this starts with interviewing customers (what Lean Startup describes as solution interviews) to get the qualitative feedback and confidence necessary to build a minimum viable product. You can also continue and expand on quantitative testing through surveys and landing pages. This provides you with a great opportunity to start testing your messaging (unique value proposition from Lean Canvas) and the initial feature set.  
åŒæ ·ï¼Œè¿™é¦–å…ˆä»é‡‡è®¿å®¢æˆ·ï¼ˆç²¾ç›Šåˆ›ä¸šæè¿°ä¸ºè§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆè®¿è°ˆï¼‰å¼€å§‹ï¼Œä»¥è·å¾—æ„å»ºæœ€å°å¯è¡Œäº§å“çš„å¿…è¦å®šæ€§åé¦ˆå’Œä¿¡å¿ƒã€‚ä½ ä¹Ÿå¯ä»¥ç»§ç»­å¹¶é€šè¿‡è°ƒæŸ¥é—®å·å’Œç€é™†é¡µè¿›è¡Œå®šé‡æµ‹è¯•ã€‚è¿™ä¸ºä½ æä¾›äº†ä¸€ä¸ªå¾ˆå¥½çš„æœºä¼šæ¥æµ‹è¯•ä½ çš„ä¿¡æ¯ï¼ˆæ¥è‡ªç²¾ç›Šç”»å¸ƒçš„ç‹¬ç‰¹ä»·å€¼ä¸»å¼ ï¼‰å’Œåˆå§‹åŠŸèƒ½é›†ã€‚

There are other practical ways of testing your solution prior to actually building it. By this point, you should have identified the riskiest aspects of the solution and what you need people to do with the solution (if it existed) in order to be successful. Now look for a way of testing your hypotheses through a proxy. Map the behavior you want people to do onto a similar platform or product, and experiment. Hack an adjacent system.

Localmind is a real-time question-and-answer platform tied to locations. Whenever you have a question thatâ€™s relevant to a locationâ€” whether thatâ€™s a specific place or an areaâ€”you can use Localmind to get an answer. You send the question out through the mobile application, and people answer.  
Localmind æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªä¸åœ°ç†ä½ç½®ç›¸å…³çš„å®æ—¶é—®ç­”å¹³å°ã€‚æ— è®ºä½ çš„é—®é¢˜ä¸å“ªä¸ªå…·ä½“åœ°ç‚¹æˆ–åŒºåŸŸç›¸å…³ï¼Œä½ éƒ½å¯ä»¥ä½¿ç”¨ Localmind æ¥è·å–ç­”æ¡ˆã€‚ä½ é€šè¿‡ç§»åŠ¨åº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºå‘é€é—®é¢˜ï¼Œç„¶åå…¶ä»–äººæ¥å›ç­”ã€‚

Before writing a line of code, Localmind was concerned that people would never answer questions. The company felt this was a huge risk; if questions went unanswered, users would have a terrible experience and stop using Localmind. But how could it prove (or disprove) that people would answer questions from strangers without building the app?  
åœ¨ç¼–å†™ä¸€è¡Œä»£ç ä¹‹å‰ï¼ŒLocalmind æ‹…å¿ƒäººä»¬æ°¸è¿œä¸ä¼šå›ç­”é—®é¢˜ã€‚å…¬å¸è®¤ä¸ºè¿™æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªå·¨å¤§çš„é£é™©ï¼›å¦‚æœé—®é¢˜å¾—ä¸åˆ°å›ç­”ï¼Œç”¨æˆ·å°†ä¼šæœ‰æå·®çš„ä½“éªŒå¹¶åœæ­¢ä½¿ç”¨ Localmindã€‚ä½†æ˜¯ï¼Œåœ¨ä¸å¼€å‘åº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºçš„æƒ…å†µä¸‹ï¼Œå®ƒå¦‚ä½•è¯æ˜ï¼ˆæˆ–è¯ä¼ªï¼‰äººä»¬ä¼šå›ç­”é™Œç”Ÿäººçš„é—®é¢˜ï¼Ÿ

The team looked to Twitter and ran an experiment. Tracking geolocated tweets (primarily in Times Square, because there were lots of them there over several days), they sent $@$ messages to people who had just tweeted. The messages would be questions about the area: how busy is it, is the subway running on time, is something open, etc. These were the types of questions they believed people would ask through Localmind.  
å›¢é˜Ÿè½¬å‘äº†æ¨ç‰¹ï¼Œå¹¶è¿è¡Œäº†ä¸€ä¸ªå®éªŒã€‚ä»–ä»¬è¿½è¸ªäº†ä½äºæ—¶ä»£å¹¿åœºçš„åœ°ç†ä½ç½®æ ‡è®°çš„æ¨æ–‡ï¼ˆå› ä¸ºå‡ å¤©å†…åœ¨é‚£é‡Œæœ‰å¾ˆå¤šæ¨æ–‡ï¼‰ï¼Œå‘åˆšåˆšå‘è¿‡æ¨æ–‡çš„äººå‘é€äº† $@$ æ¶ˆæ¯ã€‚è¿™äº›æ¶ˆæ¯æ˜¯å…³äºè¯¥åœ°åŒºçš„é—®é¢˜ï¼šæœ‰å¤šç¹å¿™ï¼Œåœ°é“æ˜¯å¦å‡†æ—¶è¿è¡Œï¼Œæ˜¯å¦æœ‰åœ°æ–¹å¼€é—¨è¥ä¸šç­‰ç­‰ã€‚è¿™äº›éƒ½æ˜¯ä»–ä»¬è®¤ä¸ºäººä»¬ä¼šé€šè¿‡ Localmind æé—®çš„ç±»å‹ã€‚

The response rate to their tweeted questions was very high. Even as you focus on a single metric, you need to be sure youâ€™re actually adding value. You should be speaking with users and customers throughout the MVP process. Now that they have a product in their hands, you can learn a great deal from them. # MVP Stickiness  
MVP ç²˜æ€§

The focus now is squarely on retention and engagement. You can look at daily, weekly, and/or monthly active users; how long it takes someone to become inactive; how many inactive users can be reactivated when sent an email; and which features engaged users spend time with, and which they ignore. Segment these metrics by cohort to see if your changes convince additional users to behave differently. Did users who signed up in February stick around longer than those who joined in January?

Qidiq is a toolâ€”for doing really simple surveys of small groups via email or a mobile applicationâ€”that was launched through startup accelerator Year One Labs. In early versions of the product, a survey creator invited respondents to join a group. Once those respondents had signed up and created an account, they could answer surveys delivered by email or pushed to an iPhone client.  
Qidiq æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªå·¥å…·â€”â€”é€šè¿‡ç”µå­é‚®ä»¶æˆ–ç§»åŠ¨åº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºå¯¹å°å‹ç¾¤ä½“è¿›è¡Œç®€å•è°ƒæŸ¥â€”â€”å®ƒé€šè¿‡åˆ›ä¸šåŠ é€Ÿå™¨ Year One Labs æ¨å‡ºã€‚åœ¨äº§å“çš„æ—©æœŸç‰ˆæœ¬ä¸­ï¼Œä¸€ä¸ªè°ƒæŸ¥åˆ›å»ºè€…é‚€è¯·å—è®¿è€…åŠ å…¥ä¸€ä¸ªç¾¤ä½“ã€‚ä¸€æ—¦è¿™äº›å—è®¿è€…æ³¨å†Œå¹¶åˆ›å»ºäº†ä¸€ä¸ªè´¦æˆ·ï¼Œä»–ä»¬å°±å¯ä»¥å›ç­”é€šè¿‡ç”µå­é‚®ä»¶å‘é€æˆ–æ¨é€åˆ° iPhone å®¢æˆ·ç«¯çš„è°ƒæŸ¥ã€‚

Only a small percentage of people who were invited actually created an account and responded. So the founders devised a test: why not act as if the recipient already had an account, send her a survey question she can respond to with a single click or tap, and see what the response rate is like? The act of responding could be treated as tacit acceptance of enrollment; later, if the recipient wanted to log into her account, she could do so through a password recovery.

The qidiq team quickly changed their application, as illustrated in Figure 16-1, and sent out more surveys to personal groups theyâ€™d created. These initial surveys were sent via email alone.
